t: “Come*pn down and sit in the dust, O*ln virgin daughter of Babylon; Sit*ln on the ground without a throne, O*ln daughter of the Chaldeans! For*ln you shall no longer be called tender and delicate.
Take*ln the millstones and grind meal. Remove*ln your veil, strip off the skirt, Uncover*ln the leg, cross the rivers.
Your*ln nakedness will be uncovered, Your*ln shame also will be exposed; I*ln will take vengeance and will not spare a man.”
Our*ln Redeemer, the Lord*s of hosts is His name, The*ln Holy One of Israel.
“Sit*ln silently, and go into darkness, O*ln daughter of the Chaldeans, For*ln you will no longer be called The*ln queen of kingdoms.
I*ln was angry with My people, I*ln profaned My heritage And*ln gave them into your hand. You*ln did not show mercy to them, On*ln the aged you made your yoke very heavy.
Yet*ln you said, ‘I will be a queen forever.’ These*ln things you did not consider Nor*ln remember the outcome of them.
“Now,*ln then, hear this, you sensual one, Who*ln dwells securely, Who*ln says in your heart, ‘I*ln am, and there is no one besides me. I*ln will not sit as a widow, Nor*ln know loss of children.’

But*ln these two things will come on you suddenly in one day: Loss*ln of children and widowhood. They*ln will come on you in full measure In*ln spite of your many sorceries, In*ln spite of the great power of your spells.

You*ln felt secure in your wickedness and said, ‘No*ln one sees me,’ Your*ln wisdom and your knowledge, they have deluded you; For*ln you have said in your heart, ‘I*ln am, and there is no one besides me.’

But*ln evil will come on you Which*ln you will not know how to charm away; And*ln disaster will fall on you For*ln which you cannot atone; And*ln destruction about which you do not know Will*ln come on you suddenly.
“Stand*ln fast*i now in your spells And*ln in your many sorceries With*ln which you have labored from your youth; Perhaps*ln you will be able to profit, Perhaps*ln you may cause trembling.

You*ln are wearied with your many counsels; Let*ln now the astrologers, Those*ln who prophesy by the stars, Those*ln who predict by the new moons, Stand*ln up and save you from what will come upon you.
Behold,*ln they have become like stubble, Fire*ln burns them; They*ln cannot deliver themselves from the power of the flame; There*ln will be no coal to warm by Nor*iln a fire to sit before!
So*ln have those become to you with whom you have labored, Who*ln have trafficked with you from your youth; Each*ln has wandered in his own way; There*ln is none to save you.
